A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.

1. The definition of a Sum of Ideals involves ideals $\frak{a}$ and $\frak{b}$ in a ring $R$. The sum $\frak{a}+\frak{b}$ is defined as $\text{{	extbraceleft}}a+b ; a \text{ in } \frak{a}, b \text{ in } \frak{b}\text{{	extbraceright}}$.

2. An ideal in a ring is a subset of the ring that is closed under addition and under multiplication by any element of the ring. A ring itself is a set equipped with two binary operations: addition and multiplication, where the addition operation forms an abelian group.

3. The definition of a Group involves a set with a binary operation that is associative, has an identity element, and every element has an inverse. Specifically, the addition operation in a ring forms an abelian group.

Since the definition of an ideal inherently involves the concept of a ring, and since a ring's addition operation forms a group (specifically an abelian group), the concept of a Group is implicitly required to fully understand and define what an ideal is, and consequently, what the sum of two ideals is.
